poem:
Begin the poem below:

Steel heart humming through cracked pavement,  
Route 21 rumbles after dusk—  
a serpent of headlights slicing neon fog.  
Its engine growls like a warning,  
each wheel spitting gravel at the curb.

I smell burnt rubber and old coffee,  
the uneasy perfume of city bones.  
Passengers fold into vinyl seats—  
shoulder-to-shoulder, breath mingling  
with the bus’s hot metal ribs.

At the edge of a lamplit alley,  
a possum shivers on the yellow line.  
Eyes like scattered marbles.  
The doors hiss; they won’t open.  
The creature trembles, abandoned,  
and the wheels click forward,  
unyielding, as if mercy were a traffic violation.

Inside, a crackle overhead—  
the driver’s voice, low and confident,  
spinning fables about subterranean tracks  
where the city’s secrets burrow  
beneath subway grates.  
He swears there’s a hidden lounge  
where brass horns wail at midnight,  
and rats in gold chains dance  
on puddles of spilled whiskey.

Outside, the streetlights stutter,  
casting the world in fractured amber.  
Sirens wail in the distance—  
a lullaby for restless souls.  
Concrete towers hatch shadows  
that stretch like hungry hands.

The bus lurches up Market Street,  
rhythm of suspension and steel cables,  
snaking through alleys slick with yesterday’s rain.  
Tin cafes exhale steam,  
and glass towers mirror ghosts of street sweepers.

I feel the pulse beneath my palm—  
the shudder of the metal beast,  
its promise to follow schedules  
with unwavering certitude.  
It’ll pass every stray creature,  
every flicker of life not written  
in its ledger of stops.

Here, on 21, the city breathes in sputters,  
lurches into the next block,  
hungers for the roar of passing wheels.  
And though it tells its tall tales  
in creaks and grumbles,  
it never, not once,  
opens wide for the little ones  
scurrying at the edge of the road.
